turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Please. I said I don't want you to do this.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Trask said I should move. Let's not make a thing of it.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I got a call from Ross this morning. Cable owned a plot of woodland -- he'd go there on weekends. They found Tom Grunemann's body buried there. They've notified his wife.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh.  Well it wasn't us city people that did it -- your fine rosy-cheeked country boy.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You're going back?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Well suppose I hadn't come downstairs. Would you just have folded up and sneaked away?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No. I was going to come up. I wanted to ask you to marry me.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You wanted to, or you are?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I am.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You could at least look at me!

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Look -- yes. I mean thanks, but -- don't you think we better be realistic?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Look at me. I'm pretty and sort of clever and very well intentioned, and dear God I'd tear your heart out!

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: How can you not think so? You know the things I can do.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: They don't scare me any more.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Doesn't scare me. I think we could handle it.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Look, why should it be yes or no? Can't we keep it going and see? I mean we can keep in touch and visit each other and see. People do that, that's realistic.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You don't believe that either, do you? Why can't you see my side?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Can you use these?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Can I carry something for you, to the car?  Will you kiss me?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No. I'm sore.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: She wouldn't be reliable anyhow -- a narcotics addict.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I believed her, Pete.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: All right, suppose it wasn't Tom Grunemann; where does that get you?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It's where it doesn't get me. I've got nothing left that connects to anything.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Then, close the case.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I better keep looking.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Where, how?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I could try Arlyn Page again. She saw much more of the Dumper than Bree Daniel.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: You just finished telling me she had nothing to offer. Not Tom, you said, the Dumper was clearly not Tom.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It's got to make sense some way.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I'm flying back out to Pennsylvania Friday; I'll fill them in on things.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: How is it back there?

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I think you're homesick.  I'll be out at my camp over the weekend. Nice right now, that touch of fall in the air, that skim of frost in the early mornings, very peaceful.  John, I'll be back here again Thursday; I'll be in touch. Lieutenant, thank you.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Sorry we had to meet here. But I'm pressed for time.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Well there's a couple --

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I read your report. I had to go along with it -- the idea of this being a wild goose chase, Tom being nowhere around --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Well as a matter of --

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I've been up country, you know my summer place, my camp. I don't even have a telephone there. This morning they sent a messenger out, that you'd been trying to call me.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I'm on my way to Chicago. Very important meeting tonight. Well -- any new developments?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Yeah, two things Pete, that --

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: You said Trask was arranging laboratory work. Police laboratory. Anything from that?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Yeah. It wasn't Tom.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I'm sorry. I don't understand.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It wasn't Tom that broke in the room.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: It has to be Tom. You said he ripped up his own pictures, he --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Not Tom. Whoever it was left a kind of souvenir, I told you, in her clothing. Semen. The laboratory got a blood group reading from that. The man was blood type 0; Tom was an AB.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Some mistake perhaps that --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No. No mistake Pete. It doesn't prove who it was -- but proves it wasn't Tom.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: You must be discouraged.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Not too bad. This brings back that Dumper in the picture.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: That who?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Dumper, the man Bree Daniel mentioned and Arlyn Page knew and Jane McKenna knew.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: You said he was no possible connection with Tom. The Page girl told you that, not Tom.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Someone's been doing all these things.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: You were hired to look for Tom, not someone.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Pete, I've got a chance to buy Jane McKenna's black book.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Call-girls generally keep a book, you know, a list of their clients. Sometimes, if a girl retires, she'll even sell it worth good money. Jane McKenna had a black book; when she died it was stolen. I've been after it a long time.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: You were hired to look for Tom.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I'm meeting a man tomorrow night. He wants to meet me on East-River Drive -- he wants five hundred dollars for the book. Can you get that for me Pete?

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I can't follow you.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Will the Company put up five hundred dollars to get Jane McKenna's list of clients?

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: No. It's ridiculous. This has nothing to do with Tom Grunemann.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It probably has the Dumper's name. It might give us some kind of new lead.  I want a look at it anyhow.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Klute, the Company's interest is Tom Grunemann. Solely and exclusively. You say you can't find Tom; all right, I'll see that you're paid off; the case is closed.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: All right, but I'm going to see that list.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I can talk it over; possibly I can get the money. When are you meeting the man?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Tomorrow evening, nine. East River Drive and 73rd Street.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Suppose I meet you there a half hour before.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Just send me a money order.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: No, I'd -- like to be in on it.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Well --

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Tomorrow. See you tomorrow night.

turns.speaker: CABLE'S VOICE
turns.text: John, how are you?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I'll be sending you on a report tonight.

turns.speaker: CABLE'S VOICE
turns.text: It's a beautiful day in Tuscarora - I don't envy you that humidity in the city.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It's not so bad.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Would you like to know what's in it? The report.

turns.speaker: CABLE'S VOICE
turns.text: What's in it?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I think Tom Grunemann's dead. I've been a lot of places - I've asked a lot of people. I've found no proof he's around. I've found no proof he was ever around.

turns.speaker: CABLE'S VOICE
turns.text: I'm sure the FBI and the Police explored that possibility.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No. They never did, really. But that's what I'm going to recommend. The next step. Unless something --

turns.speaker: CABLE'S VOICE
turns.text: Have you discussed this with them?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It's in the report.

turns.speaker: CABLE'S VOICE
turns.text: Do they have the report? Have you discussed it with them?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I wanted to give it to you first.

turns.speaker: CABLE'S VOICE
turns.text: All right. All right --  John, just sit tight will you? I'll read your report, I'll discuss it with the others. I'll be back next Thursday, we'll talk the whole thing over then. Nothing til Thursday, all right?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: CABLE'S VOICE
turns.text: Thank you. Goodbye, John.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Goodbye, Pete.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've always respected Bree.  I'd like to make something clear.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I've just got a few --

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'd like to make something clear. I don't go after a girl; a girl comes to me. Her choice. Right?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I'm looking for a man. Tom Grunemann.  Bree thinks he may have been the dumper -- that call she had two years ago. She says you sent her on it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Two years ago? Sorry.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: They tell me you use narcotics. Could I bring someone around to look at your arms?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Look -- dad -- I may stand better with the cops than you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: OK, a family matter. Between the girls. I had two other cows --  -- two other girls besides Bree.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: She told me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: OK and one of them  Jane McKenna -- she blows a little jealous of Bree - you know? -- Bree comes first? And evidently she knew the freak --- that he was a dumper -- she conned me into passing him to Bree, you know, so Bree'd get hurt. I didn't know. Till afterwards.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Why didn't you tell Bree, afterwards?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You don't tell them. That one of their own in-laws laid a dumper on them?  Peace in the family.  Beyond that, I don't know. All she wrote.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I'd like to talk with Jane McKenna.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Would I be telling you all this? She copped out long ago. She committed suicide Baxter.

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: -- Usual case history -- this isn't a medical confidence, it's all of them -- broken family, lonely, confused, crummy childhood, early promiscuity, formal prostitution beginning in her teens, income twenty-five to thirty thousand a year.  Oh they don't keep the money: they get rid of it, they get pimps. Why?  Why do you want to know all this?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I want to know how Tom Grunemann got mixed up in it.

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: Not unusual.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Did she talk about him to you?

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: About his letters -- that's all she remembered. Quite violent material, I'd say, obsessive, a quite sick man. But that's not unusual either.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Has she talked with you since prison?

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: No. She had every good intention of it -- coming to me as a private patient, getting out of the life, devoting herself to an acting career.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I think she's trying that.

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: Oh sure they try. The idea of a better life.  But they don't really know much about life: They get confused -- or scared or frustrated or bored -- they pop back to the one thing they can handle. The trick. The trick. Men in bed. Not men in general, not life, not love, not even real sex -- it avoids all that. Just the trick, the transaction.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Klute. With a K. K - L - U -

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Are you with plant security, Sergeant?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Town Police.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Then how are you involved?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I know Tom Grunemann.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: You knew the subject Thomas Grunemann. How well?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: We grew up together. Kids.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Can you account for his disappearance in any way?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Did he recently appear to you agitated or depressed?  -- indicates no -- Did he voice to you grievance or discontent with his research work here? Indicates no. Moral or sexual problems or peculiarities? --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Marital problems in general? Indicates possibly -- am I right Sergeant?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Everybody's got some, I guess.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Did he ever mention specifically a girl or woman in New York?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Examine this letter please.  We recovered that from the shredder -- the plant disposal and incinerator system. Grunemann apparently typed it Friday, before he left, decided not to send it, tossed it away. We've already contacted the New York Police; they think they know the girl in question.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: But if Cable killed Grunemann why would he get you hired to look for Grunemann?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Because he knew I couldn't leave the case alone. And this way at least he'd keep track of it. And me.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: What about Grunemann's letters to the girl, everything like that?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Sounds to me you better shake him again. Put him in a spot he has to do something more -- but this time give him a time and a place to do it.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: He called this morning from Tuscarora. Asked me to meet him at 3:00 at the downtown heliport. He's on his way to Chicago.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: That's a lot of people to die unknown.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Unknown, unidentified and unwanted. And there's more every day man, there's more everyday.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: He's right you know. Waiting for the pusher, she'd tell you anything.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I believed her: the Dumper was not Tom Grunemann.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: That's how the other one died, you know. In the water.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I looked it up.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Think this is our guy?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I don't know. It looks familiar to me.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Thought it might. It's off an arrest report you typed two years ago. Man you wanted samples of everybody.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: But what reason could he have? What possible reason?

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Unless he was involved with Grunemann's disappearance.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I knew Tom never wrote that letter.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: What else do you know?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I never could believe that Tom was a split personality. I never believed he was a Dumper; and I don't believe he disappeared of his own volition; and I don't believe he's alive.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: We have some very tentative circumstantial evidence of freeky behavior, but there's no evidence of murder - there's not even a body.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I don't believe Tom's alive.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Gov, want to leave me that one. How come he got to play with this one, anyway.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I left them here. I was doing some work here.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: It's damn lucky you didn't have the dossier on Cable here.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Nobody's seen that.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: If we get anything from the lab, we'll have it by noon. And just think -- all he really had to do was write us a letter.

turns.speaker: STREIGER
turns.text: Are you closing the case?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: No sir, we don't state that. We're countin --

turns.speaker: STREIGER
turns.text: Why couldn't you ever find out anything from the girl?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Trask --

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: The subject got emotionallv disturbed; he just dropped out. There's thousands.

turns.speaker: STREIGER
turns.text: Inspector we understand your position; ours is a little different. We have an investment in Tom Grunemann. The Company has an investment, and we feel entitled to investigate for ourselves.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Private investigation, you mean. Yes sir, of course you're entitled, and there's some very competent --

turns.speaker: STREIGER
turns.text: Klute offered us his services; we've accepted.

turns.speaker: STREIGER
turns.text: Klute knew Tom. He has a great many ideas about the case --

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Yes sir, we know he --

turns.speaker: STREIGER
turns.text: We'd expect him to work in cooperation with you. He'd report to each of you and to our Company's New York office, to Pete -- Pete goes there on a regular schedule back and forth, and --

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Mr. Streiger, speaking frankly -- we've appreciated the Sergeant's interest you know, all along. Here, locally. But New York, that's - well --

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: Mr. Kramer?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: I'm Dr. Alvarez, Judge Atkins asked me to look in on your son and prepare an evaluation sheet.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, yes.  Won't you come in.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: Where is the child?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He's in his room, playing.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: Good.  I'll see him in there.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: Mr. Kramer, do you ever have sex in here with anyone?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Doctor, I attempt to conduct my social life discreetly.  At the moment I am seeing no one.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: Does that distress you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Not particularly.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: What does?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: The prospect of losing my child.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: Very well, I'd like to see him if I may.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: What do you have here, Billy?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Detroit.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: No.  But I've been to Brooklyn.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: I see you have people there. What are their names?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: That's Kim...and this one's Thelma and that's Mrs. Willewska and this is daddy and that's Batman and over there is Robin.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: What about your mommy?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Oh, sure.  Here, this can be mommy.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: Do you like to be with your mommy?

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: What do you like best about her?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Lunch in a restaurant.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: What do you like best about your daddy?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Playing.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: Tell me, does your daddy ever hit you?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: He hits me on the planet Kriptarium, when I steal the buried treasure from the famous peanut butter factory.

turns.speaker: ALVAREZ
turns.text: In real life when does he hit you?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: My daddy doesn't hit me, silly. Why would my daddy hit me?

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: Ladies and gentlemen...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Ladies and gentlemen...

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: Welcome to the greatest show on earth.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Welcome to the...

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: Greatest.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Greatest...

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: Show.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Show...

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: On earth.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: On earth.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Huh?...Oh God...What time is it?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: The little hand is on the six and the big hand is on the nine. Where is mommy?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, Christ...Ah, yeah...you want to know why mom's not here, right?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: When is mommy coming back?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Soon.  Very soon.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'll tell you what, kiddo--why don't I fix us some French toast?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Wow!  French toast, really?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sure.  Didn't I ever tell you French toast was my specialty? I'll bet I never told you that. Now then, the first thing we need is...  ... eggs!  Right?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: You forgot the milk.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's right.  You're absolutely right...It's been a long time since I made French toast.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: What about my orange juice?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Right.  One O.J. coming up.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: When is mommy coming back?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Soon.  I told you before, very soon.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Will she pick me up after school?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.  If I'm not here, you go home with Thelma and Kim.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: What if she forgets?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'll call Thelma and remind her, okay?  Don't worry.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Uh, huh...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You got a letter from mom.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: You're late.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm sorry, pal, but I had a meeting and--

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Okay...Same as usual...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Billy, don't eat with your fingers.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well, I see the Yankees finally won a game.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Mom, I mean dad?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Can I be excused?  I'm not hungry.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sure.  Too much birthday cake, right?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I guess...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Mom, I mean dad...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh huh...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: That's not the right soap.  We use the kind in the green and yellow box.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: C'mon, there's not much difference--

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: We use the green and yellow.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Mom, I mean dad...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: In a minute...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: You get a new fence.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: C'mon, Billy.  I'm trying to work for God's sake...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Je-sus Christ!  I catch all kind of shit at the office because I'm not pulling my weight because I'm busting my butt trying to be a decent goddamn father and--

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's terrific.  That's really terrific, but I notice I'm the one that's cleaning up this--  Oh, crap, I'll have to do this one over.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, I'm sorry I yelled, okay?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: That's okay.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's just...I've been catching a lot of flack at the office...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: That's okay...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Salisbury steak.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I hate it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You don't hate it.  We had Salisbury steak last week and you liked it fine.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: No I didn't.  I hate the brown stuff.  It's gross.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: All it is is onions and gravy.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I'm allergic to onions.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You are not allergic of onions.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I want a pizza.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.  This is fine.  Just take a bite, you'll like it fine.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I think I'm going to throw up.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, for God's sake...Here.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: There, okay? Now that's just plain old hamburger.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Some of the brown stuff is still there.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Then eat around it.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Now listen to me, young man. Do you know what I had to go through to put this goddamn food on the goddamn table?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I don't care.  I hate it.  I want pizza.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Not on your life.  That's it. I've had it with crap around this house.  From now on, no more pizza!  Get it?  Starting right now you can eat real food like a normal human being!

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Owwww...You're hurting me... You're hurting me...I hate you ...I hate you...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You're no bargain either, pal.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I want my mommy...I want my mommy..

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I want my...mm...ommy...I want mmmy...mommy...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Tough shit.  You're stuck with me.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Daddy?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I'm sorry...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's okay, pal.  Go back to sleep.  It's very late.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Daddy?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh huh?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Are you...gonna go...away?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Is mom ever coming back?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You mean for good?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Oh...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Now go to sleep.  It's very late.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sleep tight.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Don't let the bedbugs bite.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: See you in the morning light.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Dad?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I love you...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Ohhh...Ohhhh...Ohhhhh...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's okay, son...I'm here... Just a little more to go... Don't worry, son...I'm here...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sleep tight.  Don't let the bedbugs bite...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: See you in the morning light...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Billy.   This is Dr. Alvarez. She would like to talk to you.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Objection.  You're leading the witness.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Objection.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Sure.  Lots of times.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: See.  That's my name.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: It's my name too.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Wow!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You like it?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Is this really your desk?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Is that really your chair?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh huh...

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Wow!  That's neat.   Can I sit in it?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Did mommy ever see this?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, she never did.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Are you going to get remarried?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know.  I hadn't thought much about it.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Are you going to remarried Phyllis?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, son.  Daddy and mommy will never get remarried.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Boy, I bet you if mommy ever saw this she'd remarried you.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Mom--I mean, dad?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh, huh?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: What did you do when you were little?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I guess about the same kind of things you do.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Did you watch "I Dream of Jeannie?"

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh, uh...We didn't have television then.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Was there apple juice when you were little?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah, there was apple juice.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Was there Burger King?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh, uh.  There was no such a thing as Burger King.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: What else wasn't there?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Daddy!  You're home early.  Did you get fired again?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, son, I didn't get fired.  I'll tell you what we'll do, okay?  How about if we go to a Burger King and then we watch a little T.V. and then we get packed to go to the country tomorrow. Just you and me...How 'bout that?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Billy, sometimes when a mother and a father are divorced, there's a discussion about who the child should live with, the mother or the father.  Now there is a man who is very wise.  He's called a judge.  And a judge has a lot of experience with divorces and he decides who it would be best for the child to live with.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Why does he decide?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Because...Well, that's what he does.  He's a very powerful man.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Like a principal?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Bigger than a principal.  The judge sits in robes in a big chair.. The judge has thought a lot about us, about you and me and your mom, and he has decided...  ...he has decided that it would be best for you to live with your mom Joanna in her apartment.  And I'm very lucky.  Because even though you'll live with your mom Joanna I'll get to see you once a week for dinner and a couple of weekends a month.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: I don't understand, daddy.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What don't you understand, pal?

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Where will my bed be, where will I sleep?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: At your mom's.  She'll have a bed for you in your own room.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Where will my toys be?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'll send your toys there and I'm sure you'll get some new ones.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Who will read me my stories?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Your mom.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Daddy, what if The Face comes when I'm at mommy's?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Your mom knows all about The Face, okay?  Don't worry, she'll tell The Face to beat it.

turns.speaker: BILLY
turns.text: Will you come and say good-night to me every night?

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Overruled.  The witness will answer, please.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Objection!  I must ask that the counsel be prevented from harassing the witness.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Sustained.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Overruled.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Sustained.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Mr. Kramer, isn't it true that you were fired from your last job not more than six weeks ago?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Are you introducing the question of negligence here, counselor?

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Yes, your honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I see.  Well, you'll have to do better than that.  Do you have any affidavits to support negligence?

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: I do not, your honor, however--

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: This is an isolated incident, counselor, unless you can prove otherwise.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Does the witness deny the injury took place?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: No, counselor, I'm going to over- rule you on this line of questioning.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Then I have concluded my questions.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Now then, Mrs. Kramer, would you tell the court how long you were married?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Six years.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: And would you describe those years as happy?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: The first couple, yes, but after that it became increasingly difficult.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Mrs. Kramer, did you ever work in a job while you were married to your ex-husband?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: No, I did not.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Did you wish to?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Yes.  I tried to talk to Ted-- my ex-husband--about it, but he wouldn't listen.  He refuses to discuss it in any serious way. I remember one time he said I probably couldn't get a job that would pay enough to hire a baby- sitter for Billy.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Tell me, Mrs. Kramer, are you employed at the present time?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Yes, I work for Jantzen as a sportswear designer.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: And what is your present salary?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I make thirty-one thousand dollars a year.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Mrs. Kramer, do you love your child?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Yes.  Very much.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: And yet you chose to leave him?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Yes...Look, during the last five years we were married, I had...I was getting more and more...unhappy, more and more frustrated.  I needed to talk to somebody.  I needed to find out if it was me, if I was going crazy or what.  But every time I turned to Ted--my ex-husband, he couldn't handle it.  He became very...I don't know, very threatened.  I mean, when- ever I would bring up anything he would act like it was some kind of personal attack.  Anyway, we became more and more separate ...more and more isolated from one another.  Finally, I had no other choice, I had to leave. And because of my ex-husband's attitude--his unwillingness to deal with my feelings, I had come to have almost no self- esteem...  At the time I left, I sincerely believed that there was something wrong with me--that my son would be better off without me.  It was only when I got to California and started into therapy I began to realize I wasn't a terrible person.  And that just because I needed some creative and emotional outlet other than my child, that didn't make me unfit to be a mother.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Your honor, I would like to place in evidence a report on Mrs. Kramer's therapy by her therapist, Dr. Elinore Freedman of La Jolla, California.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Mr. Kramer, why did you set up residence in New York?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Because my son is here.  And his father is here.  As a mother, I don't want my child to be separated from his father.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Mrs. Kramer, can you tell the court why you are asking for custody?

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Objection.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: How long do you plan to live in New York, Mrs. Kramer?

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Your honor, I would request a direct answer to a direct question.  Does she have a lover?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Mrs. Kramer, how can you consider yourself a fit mother when you have been a failure at virtually every relationship you have undertaken as an adult?

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Objection!
